SUPERIMPOSED TITLES appear and hold fo Abruptly, the image springs to life. The gun FIRES deafen branches shake violently. Another set of TITLES appears. again as a lone bugle plays a charge. Again and again and moves, the gun DISCHARGES noisily, the image FREEZES and appear with every FIRING. On the last discharge, the trumpet fades and all hell bre

Nothing but FAST, BRUTAL FLASH CUTS of: Cannon firing in all directions.  Massive explosions on the battlefield that light up the n Troops marching across a bridge as a shell hits the river towering into the sky.  An entire cavalry division galloping hard over the battle fire visible above them on the horizon. Brief shots of the horses, their grim riders hanging on f muscles flexing, hooves pounding the dirt. Men yelling.

head_text.subj: FASTER AND FASTER, MORE AND MORE CHAOTIC

text: Mortar fire, explosions, smoke. A machine gunner fires. A soldier falls. Infantrymen, rifles in hand, press through the haze. More machine gunning. More soldiers go down. A massive gun fires. SMASH CUT of a tank tread bearing down on the CAMERA, bla Infantrymen trail behind the heavy machinery, firing pist A bridge explodes. A building explodes. The ground explod A bomb drops from an airplane. Aerial view of an exploding building. Anti-aircraft guns at work. Planes in the air. A machine gun fires skyward. Planes circle, filling the air. A single bi-plane. The plane's gunner, SHEP LAMBERT, looks down, surveys the into a grin. Shep nudges his pilot, CARY LOCKWOOD, and points. Cary lo Another plane below. In it, pilot BILL TALBOT waves and s gunner, opens his mouth, smiles and nods up at them. An enemy plane arrives. The enemy pilot fires his twin machine guns. Bill and Francis' plane spins away. Bill cocks a snook at the enemy plane and waves dismissiv Francis' amusement. The planes circle in the air. The enemy plane trails Shep and Cary. Shep FIRES his mach as Cary watches. The enemy pilot returns fire. The two planes tango in mid-air. Shep FIRES. The enemy pilot grins and FIRES. Bullet holes riddle the side of Shep and Cary's plane. Cary warns Shep they've been hit. From the enemy plane's POV, Shep and Cary's plane streams The two planes. Shep and Cary's plane goes into a steep d control. Cary rips off his goggles as smoke pours up from below hi Flames fill the cockpit as Cary's gloved hands desperatel the red hot controls. The plane, streaming smoke, spins wildly downward. Shep, surrounded with smoke, looks skyward and salutes wi Above, Bill and Francis watch. Bill returns the salute wi Francis, though, doesn't look happy. Shep twists in his seat and looks around. Cary's hands grasp the controls in the flaming cockpit. Level off, Cary! Level off!

Despite the flames, Cary pulls back on the control stick. From the plane's POV: The landscape rushes by. The plane, now level, crashes into the ground and comes t Smoke. Flames. Cary jumps out of the cockpit and rushes back to Shep who clamber out.
Shep! Shep, are you all right?
Can't make it, Cary. Can't make it.
Here, give me your arm! I'll get  you out of here! Hang on there,  Shep! Get a hold - Just hold tight,  old fella.
Cary pulls Shep out and hauls him away from the burning w of them collapse to the ground, half-conscious. Flames consume the plane.
for Lieutenant Shep Lambert, a patient at U.S. Army A.E.F Shep's temperature readings for October 11th to October 2 a line on a graph, near a level marked CRITICAL. The dist continues to RUMBLE.
swings into view. This one is for Lieutenant Cary Lockwoo October 27th to November 2nd are also below the CRITICAL continues and improves considerably by November 11th when marked NORMAL.

The battle sounds are now joined by a loudly TICKING cloc energy or emotion, Shep and Cary sit together on a hospit uniform. Shep wears dark eyeglasses. Cary has a coat drap glances off. We follow his gaze, PANNING past other patie to a wall clock and calendar. It is November 11th and the eleven A. M. The battle's RUMBLE drones on.
stare up at the clock. Behind his dark glasses, Shep's le

slowly DISSOLVES to one last BRIEF BATTLE MONTAGE: soldie running, guns firing noisily, a plane crashing, explosion of a plane parked on the ground, its engine dying, its pr stop as we DISSOLVE BACK TO the clock face. The center of up exactly with the center of the propeller -- the slowin are replaced by the clock's hands -- as if to symbolicall war has ended but time goes on. The NOISE of battle fades of the clock remains. DISSOLVE TO the calendar: November Armistice Day.
sit motionless side-by-side on the cot. Shep has a hand o
Well, the old guerre is finie.
That's right.
What are ya gonna do now, Shep?
Get tight.
(turns to him) And then what?
Shep lets go of his eye and looks at Cary as if the answe
Stay tight.
Cary grins wryly.

A nurse opens a door for Shep and Cary who enter. Shep we Cary carries his coat to hide his hands. They pause as th passed through close behind them. Their distinguished-looking doctor, a medical officer wit his uniform, sits at his desk studying their papers.
Lieutenants Lambert and Lockwood.  (rises, joins them) You two leaving us, eh? In a way,  I'm sorry to release you two. I have  no choice in the matter.
Shep removes his glasses and presses his hand to his eye.
What am I going to do, Major, about  my-- oh, this rotten business?
The doctor examines Shep's eye more closely.
Mm? Spasmodic twitching of the  muscles under the eye, eh,  Lieutenant?
Mm hm.
What the French call a tic. T-I-C,  tic. Little bothersome, isn't it?
Shep puts his glasses back on.
Yes, sir.
I'm afraid time'll have to take care  of that. Time and normal living.
Shep's lips tighten skeptically.
You two are returning to the United  States, I presume?
Shep glances at Cary.
Ah, we haven't decided.
I'd take the first boat home. Well,  here you go.
The doctor gives Shep his release form and shakes his han shake Cary's. Cary merely looks down darkly and raises a
Oh, I forgot your burnt hands.
The doctor folds up the release and stuffs it in Cary's b
Neither of you is fully hospitalized.  I'd undertake a systematic course of  finger exercises -- to, uh, stretch  them and loosen them up. In time,  you'll regain their full use.
Thank you, sir.
The doctor gives Cary a pat on the shoulder.
Bye, Lieutenant.
Cary manages a smile and salutes. Shep moves to the door,
Bye, Lieutenant. Good luck.
Shep opens the door and he and Cary head out. After the d doctor rubs his head thoughtfully. He talks, apparently,
Well, there they go. Out to face  life.  (shakes his head) And their whole training was in  preparation for death.
He moves off as we

Shep and Cary exit the building but pause outside the doo something coming toward them and glance at one another be its path. They watch glumly as a small group of wounded s some metal gates, walk slowly past Shep and Cary without head into the hospital.
The office window opens. The doctor -- no longer in white uniform -- and his aide take a break, standing in the win little fresh air. The doctor smokes a cigarette as they d
Why can't they go on with flying?  You know, the air mails or  something?
I'm afraid they're unfit for further  service in that direction.
The aide looks at him, quizzically.

They fell, you know -- six thousand  meters.  (shakes his head, sadly) Like dropping a fine Swiss watch on  the pavement. Shattered both of them.  Their nervous systems are deranged,  disorganized, brittle.
Spent bullets.

Spent bullets. That's it.  (nods) They're like projectiles, shaped  for war and hurled at the enemy.  (gestures with cigarette) They've described a beautiful, high-arching trajectory. And now  they've fallen back to earth.  Spent. Cooled off. Useless.
We slowly PULL BACK from the two men.
Oh, well, if they take care of  themselves, they'll pull through  all right.
Even if they do take care of  themselves, what good are they?  What can you expect of them?  (shakes his head) I hate to think what may become  of them.
We have pulled back far enough and now we
Two uniformed men with familiar faces -- exuberant pilot gunner Francis -- arrive at the bottom of the stairs in f Bill, with his arm in a sling, and Francis, using a cane, and wave.
(Texas accent) Hello, Cary!
Hi, Cary!
At the top of the stairs, Shep and Cary wave back, please
Hello, Bill! Hiya, Francis!
Hello, Bill! Francis!
Unexpectedly, Shep and Cary hurry down the stairs past th
(friendly) Well, I see you got yours.
(pleasantly) Yup. We crashed.
Bill and Francis watch, surprised, as Shep and Cary hurry
(calls down, puzzled) Hey! Where you going?
Shep and Cary, already seated in the back of a waiting au kids.
Paris! Paris?!
From the stairs, Francis smokes a cigarette and looks dow uncertainly. But Bill takes the news in stride -- he smil at them.
See you in Paris!
(waves his cigarette) Yeah.
Smiling, Shep and Cary wave back as their car drives off.
A superimposed text reads:
Traffic noise, taxi horns squeaking.

Strolling down the sidewalk four abreast, as if they own heroes -- Bill, Shep, Francis and Cary -- in smart hats a Outwardly, they seem to have recovered from their wounds. Shep still wears his dark glasses and we occasionally gli twitching.  Cary's bandages are gone but he has not regained full use personality is dark and dry, more subdued than Shep's, an the most levelheaded, rational member of the group -- its leader. Francis seems to have suffered the greatest toll psycholo narcoleptic, strangely detached and unemotional much of t the verge of dozing off, his speech slurs even when he is Only the athlete of the group, Bill -- a burly Texan whos William Talbot -- is in outstanding physical shape. But h restless, and temperamental, covering up unnamed insecuri forced exuberance.
How 'bout a cocktail?
Not a bad idea at that.
As a group, they turn and head into a nearby building.
made of light bulbs, outside the building. It spells out popular Parisian drinking establishment for Anglo-America
Numerous shelves holding numerous bottles of liquor. Empl jackets hurriedly rush in and pull down a few bottles.

The place is packed with well-dressed men and women. The men (and men only, for no women are allowed to sit at Cla drinking, conversing. At the end of the PAN, we discover greeted by an employee who takes their hats.

An attractive young woman with a wide, vacant stare stand opposite the bar holding a champagne glass in her hands. she seems to be in a world all to herself. Our four handsome heroes file past her, intent on finding pays any attention to Nikki. After they have all passed h and stare. She's extremely nearsighted and doesn't notice glass in her hand, puzzled. He starts off but then pauses After a second uncertain look, he moves off to join his f together and peer around the crowded room, unable to find keeps looking at Nikki. He glances at the others and they
still wearing a blank expression, clutches the glass in t
in her hands. Between her fingers, we glimpse its content of men's false teeth. We PULL BACK to discover that Cary has approached her. He next to her and is staring at the glass. She finally noti
I beg your pardon. But, if I'm not  too inquisitive, would you mind  telling me what IS that you're  drinking?
Teeth.
Teeth?
After another look, Cary turns to his friends.
Hey, it's teeth! Teeth?!
Shep, Bill and Francis hurry over like children and crowd amazement at the teeth. Nikki is unimpressed by all the a
Teeth!
That's right.
(enthusiastic) Yup. It's a full set -- upper and  lower.
(to Nikki) It's a nice expression.
Hey, how come you're with those  teeth?
I was just standing here. And a nice  gentleman came along and begged my  pardon and asked would I mind  holding his teeth for a minute.
Well, what did he want you to hold  his teeth for?
Said he wanted to biff somebody.
(excited) Biff somebody?! Which way did he go?!
Just around to the right.
Come on, men! We're liable to see a  fight.
As quickly as they arrived, Shep, Bill and Francis depart them but stops to politely address Nikki who has gone bac
Would you like to come along?
(as if it were obvious) Oh, no. I have to stay here and mind  the man's teeth.
They glance down at the teeth.
Oh, of course.
Cary hurries off as Nikki's empty eyes rise to the ceilin
as it takes a combination one-two punch from a pair of fi
dropping unconscious to the floor.

enter a hallway just in time to see two Claridge's employ haul away the unconscious body. Our heroes have missed th Bill are delighted anyway. Bill brushes his hands (one of gestures) with satisfaction, as if he had thrown the punc
Well. THAT'S all fixed.
Bill straightens his bow-tie. Already the group seeks a n
Let's go back.
They head back to the bar.

Nikki, no longer standing against the wall, sits on a bar to the countertop, smoking a cigarette and holding an emp Our heroes enter and, glancing at the wall, fail to see h searching, Cary spots her at the bar.
Oh, there she is.
All four crowd around her, pleased to be in her company.
Well, we missed it.
Did something happen?
Well, they carried a guy out. (sees her empty glass) Say! What's become of the teeth?
Oh, the man came and got his teeth.
Well, what did he say?
He said thank you for holding his  teeth.
What did he look like?
I think he fell in an airplane in  the war -- and got his teeth knocked  out.
Well, why do you think he was in the  war?
Oh, he had a kind of little striped  ribbon in his buttonhole.
What makes you think he was a flyer?
His eyes.
His eyes?  (dry, to the others) You can tell a flyer better by his  ears.
The men chuckle.
Well, what do you say we have a  drink?
Fine!
Sure, here's some space.
Seats have opened up at the bar so they grab stools next the bartender:
Hello, Jean!
Bon soir, Monsieur Lambert.  Qu'est-ce que voulez-vous [?]
Martini!
Martini!
Martini!
Martiniiii!
Could I have a champagne cocktail?
Certainment, Mademoiselle.  (calls off) Quatre Martinis pour messieurs!  Champagne cocktail pour Mademoiselle  Nikki!
The men are all excited to find out her name. Francis use monocle to eye Nikki.
Nikki?!
Nikki?!
Nikki?!
For the first time this evening, Shep takes off his dark
Can you imagine that, fellas? Her  name is Nikki!
(considers the situation) Her name is Nikki. She holds men's  teeth. She sits at the bar and she  drinks champagne.
(significantly) Boys, she's gonna be a lot of  trouble.
Drinks are served. A moment of silence as they imbibe. Ni she lifts her glass, spilling some champagne. She laughs,
Oh, my, my!
Shep, who has been watching her closely, also laughs.
Poor sweet! She can't even hold her  glass!
Nikki notices Cary unsteadily using both his hands to hol
(casually) Oh, well, HE can't either. Besides,  he has to use two hands.

Nikki chuckles. A dark look crosses Cary's face as he loo down his drink. Seeing this, Bill and Francis exchange wo abruptly rises and leaves the bar. Mystified, Nikki looks who is suddenly grim and annoyed.
Course he can't hold his glass. His  hands are burned.
Burned?
You have no right to spill YOUR  drinks. He can't help himself.
Burned? How burned?
He brought a plane down on fire.
An airplane? In the war?
Shep demonstrates with his hands as he explains:
He held the stick. But his hands  began to slip. Then he held it  inside his arms. He was trying to  bring his rear gunner down alive.
Did he bring him down safe?
Well...
Shep takes a swallow of his Martini, sets down the glass.
Brought him down.
Oh, so that's why--?
Yes! That's why he can't hold a  glass.
Oh, I'm so ashamed.
Now, Cary's had a pretty thin time.  His nerves are tricky. You should  never call attention to his hands.
Cary sits with a fresh drink and is trying awkwardly to p handsome but humorless American journalist -- the unspeak and greets him casually.
Hi, Cary.
(unhappily) Oh, hello, Frink.
Cary immediately turns his attention to a menu. Rebuffed, to the bar and sees the other men. He has a friendly pat Francis and Bill.
Hello, Francis. Bill.
Frink pauses to stare at Nikki's back, astonished to find the bar. Then he turns to Shep, amused.
Shep. Drunk again?
Say, don't you know any OTHER  opening remarks? It's about all  we've heard from you for a year.
(signals the bartender) Hi! Jean!
Frink snaps his fingers at Jean and grabs a seat next to Frink's order in French.
Un sidecar.
Sidecar ... [?]
Jean moves off. Frink regards the others.
Say, why don't you fellows go home  and go to work?
Work? What kind of work?
Oh, anything useful.
What could we do? Sell washing  machines? Drive a milk wagon? Mend  old furniture or somethin'? Heh!
Go back to flying. Fly the air  mails.
Aw, we couldn't fly a kite.
Maybe a small kite.
Francis holds his fingers to indicate a very small kite.
Well, there must be something you  can do.
We've got to tend to our drinking.  We don't get much opportunity.
Lots of things going on outside.  Sun shining, trees growing, people  walking around.
Say! Is that STILL going on?
(laughs)  Sounds pretty pre-war to me.
During all this, Nikki has been in her own little world. whispers to Shep.
Hey. Don't I rate an introduction?  Who's your swell friend?
Oh, her? Just an old hussy we found  scattered around.

Around her neck, on a slender chain, Nikki carries a smal with a spring and has small rectangular lenses. She uses peering at unfamiliar objects in her helpless, nearsighte remark, she whips it out to stare at him, mildly offended to his lips and turns to her, speaking out of the side of
(off Frink) Pay no attention. Sometimes he goes  away.
Nikki looks away glumly as Shep grins at her. She turns a She raises her lorgnette for a better look at:
who sits at his table, staring into space, holding his un
is pleased to see Cary.
Oh! He didn't go.
She rises to join him.
startled, rises and stares at Nikki as she approaches.
Oh, I'm so sorry. Your hands...
She tries to take his hands but he pulls them away in hor in his pockets.
Oh, your poor hands! Your poor, poor  hands.

Wildly uncomfortable, Cary glances around like a cornered stalks away without a word, hands still stuffed in his po watches him exit the building. She realizes she's done so wrong and moves to follow him.
Oh!
But Shep intercepts her. Upset, she whimpers.
(more in disbelief  than anger) If you aren't the WORST! First, you  insult his hands and make him mad.  Then you cry over them and make him  self-conscious. Come on back here.  Come on.
He clasps her hand and leads her to:
Francis and Bill watch, disturbed, as Shep guides a cryin beside them. Shep sits next to her as she continues to so compact to fix her tear-stained face.
Well, that's torn it. He'll never  come back now.
Then we'll have to find him.
What for?
To explain how sorry I am.
(amused at her  distress) We-ell. You don't have to get so  emotional about it.
Who's getting emotional?
You are. You're coming all apart.  (hands her a glass) Here. Take a drink of this. Make  you laugh and play.
Nikki takes a sip, then busies herself with putting away Meanwhile, Bill leans in.
(to Shep) Say, what's she crying about?
She's crying on account of they  didn't wash her strawberries this  morning.
(to Nikki) Didn't they wash your strawberries  this morning? Well, there ain't a  whole hell of a lot that we can do  about that now.
(agrees, sadly) No.
Frink watches suspiciously as Shep pays the tab, rises an
Let's go.
Nikki obediently hops off her stool and Shep leads her aw toward the exit. Bill and Frink are distressed to see her Shep:
Hey! Where're you goin'?!
Oh, out.
(rises) Out where?! Out to get a drink.
Bill gestures grandly toward the bar with its many shelve
Don't you suppose you could arrange  that here?!
Nope. We gotta go somewheres else.
(without missing a beat) Okay. Come on, Francis. We got to go  somewheres else to get a drink.
Francis and Bill head out the door. After a moment, Frink
A taxi cab -- filled with Bill, Francis, Shep, Nikki and a restaurant. As it stops, Bill rises and points to someo table.
Hey! There he is!
The others look.
Where?
Come on!
The group cheers, spills out of the taxi and heads for:
where Cary sits reading a newspaper.  Cary!
Cary looks up. He rises, a little startled, and politely others crowd around him.
Say, what are you tryin' to do,  disown us?
(genuinely polite) Hello. Won't you sit down?
Sure we'll sit down. What'd ya think  we'd do? Stand around?
They all take seats around the little table. During this, for Nikki who grabs a seat of her own. When he tries to u her, Bill commandeers it for himself.
(with a wave, to Frink) Thank you.
A waiter joins them as they settle in.
Hello, Cary.
Hello, Shep. Hello, Nikki. What will  you have to drink?
Martini!
Martini!
Martini!
Martini!
Quatre Martinis?
Uh, could I have champagne, please?
Champagne? Oui.
The waiter departs. Off her order, Bill gives Nikki a loo
Boys, she's goin' to be a problem.
(explains, to Bill) That's what I started on.  (to Cary) It upsets me if I change over to  anything else.
(to Bill) There's a lot of things wrong with  this one.  (to Nikki) What were you doing at the bar at  Claridge's anyway?
Yes. Don't you know you're not  supposed to be there?
There's a sign on the wall says  ladies must sit at the back.
Can't read signs.
Well, we'll just have to take care  of her, that's all.
Do you think she's good-lookin'  enough?
Oh, I know I'm not very good- looking but--
But what?
But when I was a little girl, my  mother always said I had the nicest  hair-ribbon.

Shep laughs derisively. The others give him a look and he arrive. All the men, save Cary, snatch up their glasses. toothpicked olive and swallows his Martini whole. He watc champagne's drinking straw between her hands as if she we to start a fire.
Then there's her drinking.
What's the matter with my drinking?
You're a sissy drinker.
Well, maybe I can improve.
Meanwhile, Cary attempts -- with some success -- to drink unsteady hand. Bill inspects Nikki's mouth.
Then there's her teeth. Why, one of  'em is turned sideways.
(points) You mean this one?
That's it.
Why don't you have it turned around?
I don't have it turned around on  account of it's a kind of help.
Well, in what respect does it kind  of help?
Well, you see, when anyone kisses me  too hard, it splits my lip. And you  could tell when anyone kissed me too  hard on account of my lip would  bleed. So now I don't let anyone  kiss me -- hard.
The men are amused. Nikki sips her champagne.
Well, we'll let that pass.
Bill chuckles. Shep abruptly rises and walks off, presuma
Where's he gone?
Shep went off to sharpen his skates.
Now, about your nose.
What about my nose?
It isn't straight. It kind of turns  up at the end.
Well, when I was a little girl, I  got bumped by a swing.
How'd you happen to get bumped?
I just walked through the gate. I  was only seven.
Oh, poor dear. Didn't you see it?
I can't see very far.
Did it hurt?
It made me dizzy all day.
Well, I guess we can't hold that  against her.
We all make mistakes.
That's right. Michelangelo painted  Adam with a navel.
Bill and Nikki laugh at this. Suddenly, Nikki grows thoug
All the same, he'd look funny the  other way -- even in a painting.
They all consider this for a moment as a fresh round of d abruptly rises and walks off, presumably to the rest room
Where's he gone?
He went off to shave a horse.
Have you got a husband or anything?
No husband.
A mother?
Mother, yes. But we haven't met in  quite a long time.
Why not in a long time?
Well, on account of my mother's name  was Beulah. Now, you can't have a  mother named Beulah. So I changed it  to Jane. And that's how it all began.
An odd CHIMING sound distracts them. They look off to see
the narcoleptic, arms folded, asleep in his chair. He awa pulls a pocket watch from inside his jacket, opens it, an chiming ends and he rises without a word and exits.
Nikki watches Francis' exit curiously. Bill waves her off
He's goin' off to tame an alligator.
Who is he, anyway?

Francis used to fly with us in the  94th. The best shot in the squadron.  Brought down twelve planes. Used to  call him "Sudden Death." He lost  interest after his teammate got  killed. He's lonesome is all.
I like him.
He carries a chiming watch on  account of he's always falling  asleep in the daytime.
What kind of chimes?
Oh, Westminster, Canterbury, and  Whittington.
I'll take vanilla.
Cary puts a fist on his hip and gives Nikki an exasperate squeak. Francis, Shep and Frink return from their various down as Bill gives Nikki his opinion of Francis.
I think he's a washout.
Well, just because you're a big  bombardier and an All-American--
(interrupts) All-American what?
Halfback.
Where?
Oh, Montana State or somewhere.  Idaho or Nebraska or the Carlisle  Indians or something. Didn't you  never read about Bill? Bronko Bill  -- the Alabama Flash?
Bill grins as Nikki inspects him closely through her lorg
(skeptical) I think it's a forgery.
Bill's face falls. He looks at Nikki.
Say! What do you want me to do?  Tackle a horse?
She nods. Shep is amused.
Sure. Go ahead. Tackle a horse.
(with a dismissive wave) All right, all right, I'll tackle a  horse.
Shep looks down the street.
Here comes one now.
They all look to see:
rolling down the street in their direction.
Everyone watches as Bill rises and suddenly bolts in the
Look out, horse!
rolling along as Bill runs in and tackles the horse, lock around the animal's front legs to trip up the poor creatu
Cary, horrified, stands and yells:
Hey, Bill! Bill! Come back here!
Cary runs off, toward Bill, leaving a thrilled Shep and a a distressed Nikki. They all stare in concerned amazement pedestrians stops to watch the excitement.
(distraught) Oh, Bill!
Cary rushes up to the startled cab driver who is pulling
Hey! What's the idea -- runnin'  down my friend like that? Here!
Cary forces a wad of francs into the driver's hand. The c French but takes the cash.
of the fallen horse as the driver descends from the cab. tries to haul the horse to its feet while Cary tries to p
Never mind. Look where you're going  in the future now. You just watch out  where you're going!

Bill grabs the horse by its bridle and tries to pull it u annoyed, gets up on its own and shakes its head violently Bill hangs on and tries to calm the horse. Cary tries to Frink, Francis and the driver gather around. Bill is more petting the horse which understandably shies away from hi
(admonishes Bill) Now listen, come on out here, you  old fool.  (to the shying horse) Whoa, whoa.
Nice horsie.
(to Bill) Now, listen, you ought to be ashamed  of yourself. You old fool! You know  what you'll do? You'll kill yourself  one of these days. Now, come on, get  out of here. Now, listen--
Satisfied with the outcome of all this, Bill heads back f
(to the driver) You all right now, brother?
The driver nods but is more concerned with reining in his
All right. Now, you just keep your  horse, see? You got your money.
The cabbie salutes Cary but pays more attention to his ho
The waiter sets out a fresh round of drinks as the group dusts off the sleeve of his dinner jacket. Cary, beside h seat. They all sit down under the following:
Hey, listen, Bill, you're All- American, see? You're TWO All- Americans! The lady's convinced  you're the whole team. You don't  have to tackle any more horses.  How 'bout that? Drink your drink.
(pleased with himself) Ahhh. Wasn't that a great spill?
Nikki abruptly rises.
Hey! Where are you going?
Would you all excuse me for a  moment?
Well, where are you going?
(a grave announcement) To take a Chinese singing lesson.
Francis immediately understands that she's become one of olive in the air and cheers:
Hooray!
The men rise and all but Frink cheer her lustily as she d
Hooray! Hooray! Hooray! Hooray!
walks proudly into the restaurant as the men cheer. A smi directs her to the ladies' room.
Frink watches Nikki disappear from view and, after a glan rises and follows her. Shep, Bill and Cary remain at the drinking. Bill turns to Cary with a smile.
Hey. What kind of a girl do you  think Nikki is?
Cary glances in Nikki's direction and tells Bill confiden

They move toward the cafe. As Cary hangs up his hat, a wa
What should I drink now, do you  suppose?
Cary orders the drinks as Nikki moves to sit at a table.
(to the waiter) Deux picon citrons.
The waiter acknowledges this and heads inside, calling ou bartender. Cary joins Nikki at the table and sits down. S and fixes her face while he takes out a cigarette and lig following:
Picon citrons?
Very refreshing. Make you laugh and  play.
(amused)  That's what you always promise.  (suddenly serious)  Cary, why does Shep Lambert go on  drinking so desperately?
Don't we all?
Not like Shep.
Well, Shep has that tic under his  eye, you know. Takes a lot of drinks  to keep that quiet.
But isn't there some kind of  treatment or something?
Shep could never stand a long course  of treatment. Drinking's the only  corrective so far as he's concerned.  He's found out the tic doesn't work  when he's tight. So he stays tight.
The waiter arrives with the drinks. As he spritzes seltze glasses, Cary leans over to light a cigarette for Nikki. they drink.
Seems such a pity. How did he get  the tic?
In the war.
I know. But how?
Well, it's not very romantic.
Well, don't tell me if you don't  want to.
Well, you see, a tic is a nervous  habit.
Yes?
Lice under his bandages.
Oh.
He had the devil of a time. He  nearly lost his mind. So you'll have  to excuse him a little.
I'm so sorry for Shep.
Well, don't let him know it.
Well, isn't he going home? Not ever?
Not ever. Not in his dark glasses  anyway.
Can't something be done for him?
He'll have to be - reborn.
How's he going to end?
Well, how are you going to end? How  am I going to end? How is ANYONE  going to end? How's your picon  citron go?
It goes fine. But doesn't ANYTHING  make any difference to you?
Not now. A long time ago, perhaps,  when I was a little boy.
Tell me, where were you little?
In Minnesota. On a farm.
Were you happy then, Cary?
I think so.
Tell me, what WAS there to be happy  about on a farm in Minnesota?

(lost in thought) Ohhh, thorn-apple trees in blossom.  The smell of burning leaves in the  fall. The sound of horses' hoofs on  the road.  (looks at Nikki) Did you ever dig up an Indian mound  or uncover a nest of baby field  mice? Or explore old trunks in an  attic? Listen to the moaning of the  telephone wires in the winter wind?  See a gypsy caravan?
(enthralled) So THAT'S why you were happy. On  account of apple blossoms and field  mice and telephone wires and gypsy  caravans and old trunks and things?
That's right.
Nikki exhales, drinks, looks at Cary and shakes her head.
But aren't you going back? Not ever?
Would you like another picon citron  before you go? The rain is lifting.
Nikki finishes the last of her drink.
No. I'm ready now.
Cary leaves some money, Nikki gathers her things. They ri
Cary and Nikki stroll into view, arm in arm, and look aro stopped. They are the only living people in the ancient c
Who all is buried here?
Oh, poets, painters, philosophers--
Cocoanut?
No cocoanut. Poets, painters,  philosophers, musicians.
They've paused. Cary looks around, points with his cane.
There's Chopin.
Oh, I practiced him.
He gives her a look and they move on.
And there's Balzac. And there's  Heloise and Abelard.
Oh, tell me about Abelise and  Eloard.
No, Nikki. Not Abelise and Eloard.  Heloise and Abelard.
I'm sorry. I really didn't do it on  purpose. It was on account of the  picon citron. Tell me about Heloise  and Abelard.
Well, they're buried here in the  same sepulchre side by side.
Why are they buried side by side?
They stop.
They were the world's most famous  lovers.  (looks off, points  with his cane) There's the tomb.
They approach the large tomb which is fenced off by a low removes his hat, Nikki peers at the double sepulchre thro
Tell me about the world's most  famous lovers.
Well, Abelard was a scholastic  philosopher--
Whatever that is.

Whatever that is. He gained a  footing in a certain household as  tutor to a maiden called Heloise.  And employed his unlimited  opportunities for the purpose of--  Well, betrayal. Not, however,  unmixed with real love. He carried  her off to Brittany.
Tell me more.
Well, her uncle was furious. He  blamed Abelard for the whole thing.  He conceived a terrible revenge.
(uneasy) I'm afraid for Abelard.
He broke into Abelard's apartment  one night and perpetrated upon him  the most brutal punishment.
Oh, dear.

The lovers were forced to live  their lives apart. But when they  died, they were buried here side by  side.  (peers down at  the ground) There's a story that little heart- shaped stones are supposed to grow  around the tomb.
Heart-shaped stones?
And lovers come and find them and  exchange them with each other.  (looks at Nikki) And, so long as you keep the stone  from the tomb of Heloise and Abelard,  no harm can come to your true love.
How perfectly beautiful.
Isn't that a quaint legend?
They crouch at the iron bars of the gate surrounding the their gloves under the following:
Do you think I might find a heart- shaped stone? You help me, Cary.
All right, Nikki. Only we have to  leave soon.  (looks off) They close up the place.
Just as soon as we find our stones.
They reach through the gate to poke at the rocks and grav tomb. After a moment, Nikki rises and walks off excitedly hand.
I found one! Where's yours?
Cary, too, finds a stone and rises to join her.
as the couple sits near the tomb. They show each other th upturned hands. Nikki takes the heart-shaped stone from h in Cary's stiff, weathered hand. Then she transfers his s
And, now, you take mine. And I'll  take yours.
They close their hands over the stones as we PULL BACK to Nikki and Cary smiling at one another.
Isn't that the way the story goes?
That's right, Nikki.
And, now, no harm can come to our  true love.
(amused) And, now, we'll have to go.
He starts to rise but she puts a hand on his arm.
You were so nice to let me come  with you. I spoiled your whole day.  You were going to do something else,  weren't you?
(looks away) Doesn't matter.
Well, what was it, Cary? Why did you  come here today?
(not looking at her) To pay my respects to an old comrade.
Oh. And you wanted to be alone. I'm  sorry. Oh, I'm so sorry.  (begins to weep softly)  Don't pay any attention to me, Cary.  I can't help it. You MAKE me cry.
He stares at her, astonished, as she rambles on.

Oh, don't look so troubled, Cary.  I'm all right. I just want to cry  for a minute.  (puts a hand on  his shoulder) On account of you're so nice. You're  so clean, Cary. And your teeth are  so white. You're so civilized. You  don't care about anything any more,  nor anybody. Nothing makes any  difference to you. Nothing can  touch you.  (realizes) Why, you're lost. You're ALL lost.  You and Shep and the rest of you.  (takes his hand) Oh, I want to do something for you.  I want to help you.  (looks at his wrist) Let me wash your bracelet, Cary.  (points) Why, see? The silver's all  tarnished. The silver's all  tarnished.  (removes his bracelet) I'll take it with me and scrub it  when I get home. I'll polish it  with my nail-brush.
Nikki turns to put the bracelet in her purse. Thoroughly emotional outburst, Cary looks around.
It's getting dark.
Cary rises, deeply uncomfortable. Nikki tries to make ame
Well ...  (rises, cheerily) Anyway, we found a name for my  turtles!
Cary turns and looks at her, amazed.
Heloise and Abelard? A name for  your turtles? So that's what you  were looking for. I might have  known how it would end.
He looks down at the heart-shaped stone held awkwardly in thumb brushes the stone and it falls to the ground.
Nikki sits, soberly polishing Cary's bracelet with her na enters, drink in hand.
Hi, Nik.
She looks at Shep forlornly.
(sadly)  Hello.
Shep walks over and confronts her.
Cary's in a state. Says he's going  away. Can't stand it any longer and  all that sort of thing.  (sits on the bed) What happened between you two,  anyway?
Cary seemed so sad and everything --  on account of I'd taken up his whole  afternoon.  (sighs) So little Nikki said, all merry and  bright, "Well, anyway, we'd found a  name for my turtles."
A name for the turtles?
Shep cracks up with laughter and falls backward on the be over the edge.
That's funny!
Shep keeps laughing, twists around on the bed and sits up
Name for the turtles! That's so  funny, all right!
Shep holds a hand to his head and catches his breath as N bed.
Why do you always HAVE to be funny  at the wrong time? Didn't I tell you  Cary was brittle? How did he respond  to THAT line?
(morosely)  Pulled down the iron curtain.
Shep cracks up again. Worried, Nikki tugs at his sleeve.
Did he say he was going away?
(through his laughter)  Yup. Gotta get away from it all.
Then, you've got to go to him right  now!
Nikki rises and urgently pulls Shep, helpless with laught
And explain that I didn't mean  it! Tell him how it was and  everything!
Listen--
No, go on. You go right now before  it's too late!
She pushes him toward the door.
But Nikki--!
You go right straight to Cary.
They exit.
Cary removes clothes from a rack as a now serious Shep, d nearby trying to reason with him.
Now, listen, Cary, you don't have to  behave like an old Easter egg.  You're breaking Nikki's heart. She  doesn't know any better.
She doesn't know any better? Well,  whether she does or not, I'm going  a long ways away from Nikki. Nikki  and her turtles.
Whew! You sure are in an uproar.  What YOU need is a drink!
Cary packs a weathered suitcase.
I need more than a drink. I need a  lot of geography between me and that  girl.
Where do you want to go?
Anywheres. So long as it's a long  way from Nikki.  (pauses, looks at Shep) You know -- that girl does things to  me.  (back to packing) I've got to get away.
Well, I wonder what's happening in  Portugal tonight.
Cary stops packing and gives Shep a look.
Say ...  (thinks it over) I wonder what IS happening in  Portugal tonight.
Shep stares at Cary, astonished, and moves off. Cary sets upright.
Bill and Shep set a large steamer trunk upright.
Heave ho!
Bill opens the trunk.
Ah! There you go.
Nikki appears, carrying a suitcase.
If Cary's going to Portugal, why  can't we go to Portugal, too? Ain't  we got any rights?
Sure we got rights!
Getting organized for their own impromptu Portuguese expe and Shep fill the trunk with Nikki's things as Frink lean cigarette and eyeing Nikki coolly.
Cary better not think he can screw  up in Portugal and leave old Shep  behind.
Say, when's he leaving?
Ten-thirty in the morning. Sud  Express.
Don't we have to have passports and  things?
Sure we gotta have passports!
Bill joins Nikki.
What kind passports you like?
What kind passports you got?
We have ebony, cocoanut,  thornberry passports.
(grandly) I'll take vanilla.
She brushes past him and crosses to a table where she is
Good night, Nikki. I'll see you on  the train.
You're goin', too?
Why not?  (with a sly smile) I might, uh, pick up a couple of  features for my paper - in  Portugal.
Frink walks out the door. Nikki sighs a little and then b carrying items the trunk. Shep arrives with a selection o group crowds together. Chaotic overlapping dialogue:
Nikki, do you want --?
Did you put all my shoes in?
You bet. There they are--
I don't know how you're going to get  all these dresses in, Nikki.
From the trunk, we
A mountain of trunks and other luggage piled on the floor near Shep who finishes packing a suitcase on the floor.
Don't we have to go like anything?  The train leaves in twenty minutes.
Francis leans casually on the towering pile of luggage. B him, smoking a cigarette and calling ironically to Nikki:
Are you SURE you have everything?
(misses the irony) I - I think so.
Francis clicks his tongue as he regards the pile.
(dryly) Hardly seems enough.
Suddenly, Nikki gasps and rises.
Oh, my turtles! My turtles!
are plucked from the tub and placed in ...

by Nikki's little Asian maid. The fancy beribboned wicker oversized handle which makes it a rather improbable turtl secures a wire mesh covering over the basket and carries bathroom, handing it grandly to Francis.
Here you are, Francis! You're the  custodian of the turtles! Now don't  fall down on the job.
Bill walks off. Francis calls after him, worried:
Hey! I never tended turtles before.
Nikki arrives with a bottle of water and soaks her hand.
Now, all you have to do -
She gives Francis the bottle and sprinkles the turtles wi hand.
- is to sprinkle 'em now and then, like  this.
Oh, yeah. I see.
Some of the water ends up in Francis' eye which he wipes ribbon. Nikki walks off and Francis practices soaking his the turtles.
Five bellhops march in and, under the direction of Nikki to carry off the luggage, chattering in French.
Well, we're off.  (to a bellhop,  about the trunk) Be careful of that one.
Burdened with luggage, the bellhops file out through the in hand, follows them out, beckoning to Francis behind hi
Uh, come on, Francis! Take those  turtles!
Francis hurries along carrying the basket, followed by Sh
A whistle BLOWS. Their luggage already aboard, Francis, N walk down the platform, parallel to the train. Bill claps exuberantly.
There she is, boys! The Sud Express!
Can you imagine Cary tryin' to run  away and leave us behind?
Bill laughs. Nikki peers at the train through her lorgnet
Do you suppose he's really gonna  be here?
Sure he'll be here. He's never  missed a train in his life.
Say, do you suppose the turtles'll  be all right with that porter?
Bill gives Francis a supportive pat on the back.
Aw, sure they'll be all right. All  you got to do is - (gestures with his hand) - sprinkle 'em!
Francis nods soberly. Bill laughs. Nikki points, excited.
There he is!
Cary buys a paper from a newsboy and steps onto his train Say, Cary!
On the train steps, Cary stops and turns as his friends a around him, grinning.
Hello, Cary.
(surprised) Well, hello. What are you all doing  down here?
We just came down to see you off is  all.
Well, that's darn decent of you.
Ya got a nice seat?
Yeah, right by a window.
Oh, how nice for you!
(with childlike desire) Come on! Show us your seat by the  window!
(cheerful, insistent) Yeah, come on, Cary! We wanna SEE  that seat by the window.
Climbing the steps, Bill and Shep crowd a confused Cary a train. Following the others, Francis helps Nikki up the s
Come on, Nikki.
They all board the train and head for:
The group crowds into the small compartment.
My, my, what a swell train.
Sud Express, Train de Luxe. Say,  I wonder if a chap can get a drink  on this train.
Sure! I don't see why not. Push the  button.
Bill pushes a button for the porter.
(flustered) Well, I'm afraid you won't have time  for a drink. We're gonna start in a  minute. You'll have to get off.
Everyone but Cary grabs a seat. Astonished, Cary stares a
Get off?! Gosh, no. We LIKE this  train!
This is a Train de Luxe.
Yes, we like trains de luxe, don't we,  Nikki?
Sure! Trains de luxe is what we like.
The whistle BLOWS. Cary panics.
Hey! He's blowing the whistle.  (grabs Shep's shoulder) Hey, we're gonna start.
Well, let her start.
The trains starts. Bill jauntily throws his hat up to the and the others settle in for their journey.
Let 'er go Gallagher. Who cares?!
Who cares?!
Who cares?!
Who cares?!
Frink enters casually.
Hello, everybody.
Cary is stunned. Frink sits down with the others.
And you, too?
That's right.
The group takes in the train's departure with perfect com and looks at them for a moment before breaking into a und
That's right. Who cares?
Cary sits. As the train hurtles out of the now empty stat turns to the window and waves goodbye to no one at all:
Goodbye! Goodbye! Don't forget to  write!
Shep, Bill and Francis quickly join in, waving and shouti Cary's amusement. Even Frink manages a smile at this.
racing down the track.

text: The compartment doorway. We hear the men laughing. Bill - necktie loosened and his coat off -- appears in the doorw train's corridor.
Hi, men! Look what I found.

With a grand gesture, Bill presents an elderly British ge him into the little room, greeted with a cheer of "Hooray sit around, similarly coatless (save Frink), smoking and Various bottles stand on a central table. The old gentlem but it's never clear whether he is an old friend or a tot

Sit down.
Have a drink.
Ah, thank you, no, not I.
Bill and the old gentleman sit down. Nikki dozes in her s The basket of turtles hangs from above.
I - I say, are you all going to  Portugal?
Yup. We're going down there to  investigate conditions.
Investigate conditions?
Drinking conditions, mostly.
By the way, what ARE conditions?
Don't you know what conditions are?
No. Never saw one in my life.
The drinking conditions are pretty  bad right here.
(chuckles skeptically, glancing at the bottles) Ahh, indeed.
My beer's full of cinders.
Good for ya. Make ya lay hard-shelled  eggs.

Nikki wakes, rises, and clutching her pillow, heads for t

Going to bed? Who ever heard of such  a thing?
Bill rises to confer with her at the door.
Can we help you undress?
No, thank you, William.
The old gentleman looks rather astonished at this casual
Take off your shoes?
Undo your hair?
Scrub your back or something?
No, I can manage quite well by  myself. Good night, everybody.
The men say, "Good night." Frink, who has been watching N eye, is the most polite:
Good night, Nikki.
Nikki turns and disappears down the corridor. The old gen with a handkerchief and stuffs it in his collar.
Can you imagine that ungrateful old  trollop? She wouldn't let them help  her undress.
Can't understand it at all.
You know, she's not very pretty. But  when she was a little girl, her  mother always said she had the nicest  hair-ribbons.
Indeed?
She got one tooth turned around, she  can't see very far, and she's ALWAYS  speaking out of turn. Otherwise,  she's a mighty fine piece of  architecture.
Mm, seems to need a few repairs.
During the next exchange, Frink, seated by the door, grin then notices Francis dozing off. Frink cautiously rises a corridor without anyone noticing his departure.
She's got eyes like an Assyrian  Queen's got eyes.
You ain't never seen no Assyrian  Queen! You're just a-makin' that up  outta yore own head!
I did SO see an Assyrian Queen.
In whose green hat?
In the Metropolitan Museum's green  hat, that's whose green hat.
Francis' pocket watch CHIMES. He wakes, rises, puts on hi absently toward the door. Seeing this, Shep, Bill and Car "Whoa!" Francis pauses in the doorway and sleepily turns

Sorry.

Sprinkle the turtles?

Hm?

Cary!
What's that?
Hm?
The men hear Nikki SCREAMING.
Nikki!

Cary! Bill! Shep!

Cary!

Frink turns back to a defiant Nikki as Cary enters and se slumped against the wall, clutching his head. Cary grabs spins him around.
Say, what's the idea?
What's the idea? Well, what business  is that of yours?
By now, Bill and Shep have entered and joined the tense c
Nikki, you all right? What is this  tough trying to do to you anyway?
Well, I was just going to bed and he  came in and flang himself all over  me.
Frink, you'd better get out of here  right away before something happens  to you.
What right have you to tell me to  get out of here? This isn't your  compartment, is it?
Oh, I see. You wanna argue about it.  If you don't clear out of here right  now, you're liable to get hurt.
All right. Suppose you put me out.
(savagely) Put him out? I'll snap his spine and  throw him off the train!
Cary rolls his eyes at this remark and wisely holds Bill
Hold everything, Bill!
Distraught, Nikki sinks down on a chair.
Oh, dear, does everybody have to act  like this?
Frink turns to her in protest.
I'm not gonna let these silly drunks  tell ME where to get off.
Silly drunks?!
Silly drunks, did you say?
Yes. And that goes for the whole  bunch of you.
Let me have him.
(to Bill) Wait a minute. I'll take care of  him.
You will, eh?

Socko!

Cary, fist still tightly clenched, stands over the dazed brightens considerably and wipes his hands with delight.

Will you be all right now, Nikki?
(unsure) Uh huh.
(to Bill and Shep) Grab hold of that fella and drag him  out of here.

Cary, wearing a robe, sees Shep still asleep in bed. Cary sits on the edge of his own bed opposite Shep's, picks up blows into it, hard. The horn SQUEALS horribly. Shep wake sits up in bed, completely unnerved. Cary laughs at him a hands, picks up a bottle.

Beer.
Beer.

Hey, drink your drinks! We'll miss  the parade!
The group hurriedly finish and exit. Shep pays the tab. B old man, shakes his pant leg and limps along after the ot

The crowd CHEERS and the band PLAYS as a parade of matado banderilleros enters the ring. Led by their guide, Pedro, the group takes seats in the f trenches. They have to sit close down so Nikki can see th man from the bar tags along behind Bill like a puppy dog to him but Pedro pointedly directs him to a seat in the s When Bill rises to cheer the parade, the drunken old man him affectionately on the shoulder. Bill turns and greets shaking his hand.
Well! My old pal!
The old man tips his hat to Bill and sits. Bill shakes hi the old man a wry look before also sitting.
The parade ends. A matador throws his montera (his black crowd.
Cary catches the hat, much to the group's delight -- they Immediately, a cape is hurled at Bill who drapes it over them. Cary offers the hat to Nikki.
Nikki, here's a present for you.
Oh, a hat!
Oh, senor, no, no, no -- you must  not keep the hat. You must put a  little present in it and return it  to the matador after the fight.
What kind of present?
Well, eh - a little jewelry.  Something you have like the chain or  the watch or the - the - the  cigarette case or the cuff links or  - or the--
Vanilla?
Yes! Vanilla!
A trumpet FANFARE. The crowd CHEERS. Bill points, excited
Look! Here he comes!
A bull charges into view. Bull-fighter and bull face off. passes, faster and closer each time.
Bill sits next to Pedro.
Nice work! Good work.
What's so good about it?
He works close to the bull.
Is that so dangerous?
Sure, it's dangerous. Bull-fighting  is very dangerous. It takes a lot of  courage to go into the bull ring.
Bill scoffs and waves dismissively. Cary leans in with a
Is it true the bull is blind when he  charges?
He sees only the cape -- perhaps.
Bull-fighter and bull continue their duel. Finally, the b advantage and others must rush in to distract the bull.
Bill is unimpressed.
Bet I could run that bull bow-legged.  You know, I should have BEEN a  bull-fighter.
You should have started at twelve  years of old.
I bet I could start right now.
(puts a hand on  Bill's shoulder) Sit still and behave yourself.
Bull-fighting is not for Americans.
You think we haven't got the nerve  or something?
Why, listen, bull-fighting is just  for us, the Latins.
He thinks we're a-scared!
(helpfully) He tackled a horse once.
(stares at Bill) Tackle a horse?
Full of himself, Bill nods.
(turns away; flatly) Is not the same!
Everyone suddenly stares in shock as:
the bull knocks down the matador. Others rush in to distr runs wild, out of control.
Frink nudges Francis awake and points out the carnage in glances at the spectacle briefly and then sleepily applau look and nudges him to stop clapping. Francis simply goes

The toreros try to control the bull but it refuses to coo The crowd watches intently. Bill takes off his own hat an matador's cap that Cary had caught. Toreros scramble and run for their lives. The bull chases across the ring, forcing them to jump the barrera, the pr barrier that circles the inside of the arena.  Bill, now wearing the cap, can't resist leaning over and toreros who huddle in the callejon, the safe side of the him.
Nice work, Tony! Nice work, Joe!

The toreros look up at Bill in surprise. One of them resp with a gesture toward the ring, as if to ask "If it's so try it?" The other toreros laugh. Bill stares into the ring, a savage look in his eyes. He railing. He jumps down into the ring.
Hey!
Cary rises, stunned.
Bill! Come back here!

But it is too late. Bill's coat is already off and he wav he stalks after the bull. The bull turns and sees him. Bill moves toward it, waving his coat and grinning like a Shep is frozen. Beside him, Nikki screams and turns away. The bull begins to charge. Cary climbs over the railing. The bull charges. TRACK FAST TOWARD Bill who holds the coat before him -- b The bull is on him. The bull roars. Bill's face snaps backward in a blur, his coat follows.  The bull gores him through his coat. His face twists in p CUT WIDE as the bull knocks Bill's body around the ring l hits the ground hard. Screams from the crowd. Four toreros rush in. They surround and distract the bull. Bill lies motionless Cary runs across the ring. More toreros and others rush in, surrounding the bull, fi In the front row, Shep, Nikki, Francis, Frink and Pedro w .... ... toreros converge on Bill and try to move his body. Ca
Bill!
But Bill is unconscious. A torero says something to Cary and the others lift Bill.
Take it easy! Take it easy!
They carry Bill off.
A group of toreros straighten their gleaming spangled jac reveal Cary standing over a bloodied Bill and holding his personnel prepare to operate. Bill lies flat on a table a with himself.
Cary? I slipped.
Too bad. You were doing fine.
Wasn't I, though? Heh. It's a cinch.  Bull-fighting? Just as easy--
Bill breaks off and raises his head to look at the doctor
Hey, Doc?! Be careful. What are you  doing?
To distract him, Cary pulls out a handkerchief and mops B glistens with sweat.
You know why I slipped, Cary?
No, Bill. Why?
On account of that beer in my shoe.
Bill breaks off and raises himself up again.
Hey, Doc!
Cary gently eases Bill's head back down.
Cary, that bull certainly was  hostile.
Pedro escorts Shep (in his dark eyeglasses again) and Nik doctor, in surgical gear, puts on gloves and looks annoye
You hurt, Bill?
You all right, Bill?
Sure. I'm all right. I was a big  success.
The doctor has some sharp words for Pedro who acknowledge the others:
He wants that we should go right  away.
Pedro exits.
I'm sure glad that I - I wore my new  blue shorts. I'll be a big success  in the hospital.
Nikki places a hand on his head.
I'll send you my turtles, Bill. And  THEN you'll be a big success.
She turns away, trying not to cry. Shep follows her as th
So long, Bill.
So long.
Shep follows Nikki out.
Goodbye, Bill.
Bill reaches up and pats Cary on the shoulder. Cary looks at Bill, before retreating to the door. He turns to look grins at him.
See ya later - Cary.
Cary can't return the smile. He turns and goes, closing t Bill's attention turns to the doctor whose approaching sh wall behind him. Bill's smile fades.
Cary emerges and joins the group who are gathered glumly
How is he?
They've just put him to sleep.
Nikki, emotionally fragile, hands Cary his hat.
Why, thank you, Nikki. There's  nothing you can do. You'd better go  back to the hotel.  (to Francis) Put Nikki in a taxi. We'll wait here.
As Frink and Francis exit with Nikki, Pedro approaches Ca journalists.
Senor, the reporters want to know  why your friend descend into the  bull ring.
Cary looks off and thinks for a moment.
Tell them -- that it seemed like a  good idea - at the time.
Pedro stares at Cary in astonishment. Cary joins Shep and stand with their backs to the others as we

The amusement park at Port Mayer. Crowds, carnival NOISES appropriate MUSIC. At a nearby refreshment stand, we find the group, minus B unusually silent and wearing dinner clothes. Francis hold Frink leers at Nikki who ignores him while she, Shep and drinks. They hear:
They look over to see: A little shooting gallery where customers rent genuine gu colorful targets and win prizes.
Sounds like old times.
Let's go and shoot.
Not a bad idea.  (to Nikki) What say, Annie Oakley? Like to  fire off a gun at something?
No objection.
(to their bartender) We'll be right back. Hold  everything.
The group starts over to:
where an assortment of rifles and pistols are neatly laid escort Nikki to the arsenal while Frink and Francis tag a attendant joins them to collect their money and ready the
First one to miss pays for the drinks.
What'll we shoot at?
Shoot one of those pussycats and see  what happens.
All right. Look out, pussycat.
Shep FIRES and misses the moving cats that float across t on an endless chain and disappear. But he hits a tinier t behind them. Shep's eyes pop with surprise.
Well, that's what I was aiming at,  a clay pipe.  (stares in amazement) Whole thing's been misrepresented  to me.
Cary laughs at him.
Cary, let's see you shoot something.
Cary takes careful aim.
Look out, ball!
He FIRES and hits a ball balanced atop a stream of water.
What'd YOU aim at?
Well, let's see you shoot something.

Nikki awkwardly raises her little target rifle to her sho barrel describes uncertain circles in the air. A multiple view shot of the targets reveals that Nikki is a little t handling a gun. Cary moves to help her.
Oh, no, no, no, Nikki.
How do you hold it still?
Listen, Nikki, on your right  shoulder. Now, put your hand out  there and hold up-- No, don't cover  up the site. No, no, no, that's  right. Now just hold it evenly--

Rapid GUNSHOTS. Cary looks up in surprise. He and Shep tu amazement as Francis cuts loose with an automatic rifle, row of pipes with split-second firing. The others cheer as Francis lowers the weapon and stares astonished and, apparently, very drunk Frink. Cary takes encourage Nikki.
You can do better than that. Show  him up.
She again tries unsuccessfully to hold the rifle steady. up a pistol and imitates her.
What are you waving at, Nikki?
Cary sees Frink pointing his gun at Nikki and moves to in Frink's wrist with both hands.
(angry) Look out! Why, you fool. Don't you  know better than that?
Shep and Francis move to shield Nikki.
What's the idea?
Pointing a loaded gun at Nikki?
Take your hands off me.
Put down that gun!
Let go of my wrist!

Frink violently pulls free of Cary's grasp and, as he doe with a BANG. Francis hurries Nikki to safety in the oppos backs away, clutching his side -- for a moment, it looks been hit. Cary pursues and confronts Frink.
Put down that gun!
Frink backs up to a nearby lamp post and, wielding the pi Cary. His face is tense, savage.
Listen, you keep your hands off me!  I've had enough from you! You try  any more of your rough stuff on  me--!
A nervous crowd of passersby pauses to watch the showdown
Oh, so that's how it is. I thought  we taught you how to behave.
Frink, drunk and frustrated, starts to lose it completely
You taught ME how to behave?! Listen,  you'd better behave now or you'll  get hurt!
(calmly) I don't think so. I'll give you  three to put down that gun. It'll be  just too bad if you don't.
Too bad for who?!
Frink cocks the hammer.
One ...
Cary moves slowly toward Frink.
Keep away from me! I'll shoot, I  tell ya! I'll shoot!
Two ...
Frink and Cary are less than a yard apart.
I'll shoot! I'll shoot!

GUNSHOTS. Cary flinches. Frink drops the pistol, his face starts to fall. Nearby, Francis coolly FIRES his rifle, pumping seven bul Members of the crowd SCREAM in terror. Instinctively, She his side) and Nikki each put a restraining hand on Franci lowers the rifle, staring in horror and amazement at what
Francis?
Cary rushes over and pulls the rifle out of Francis' hand
Francis?
Francis snaps out of his trance as Cary hurriedly returns gallery. Shep and Nikki watch, stunned, as Francis immedi and shakes his hand.
Goodbye, Cary.
Francis turns to Shep and Nikki for equally heartfelt han on his face.
Shep. Nikki.

They realize he is saying a final goodbye. The crowd pres glances back at Frink before turning and hurrying off.  As a huge crowd rushes in the direction of the shooting g threads his way through it in the opposite direction and, briefest glance backward, rounds a corner to disappear be Cary stares at Frink's body as the gathering crowd stream quickly starts to lead a shaken Shep and Nikki away from
We've got to get out of here. Come  on, Shep. Come on.
They slip through the thick fringe of excited people fast of the shooting gallery and hurry off in the same directi now:

on a dark, deserted street. Distant crowd NOISE and carni Under the light of a street lamp on the edge of the carni casually into view and swings a leg over a slackly hung b to glance backward. He sees ... ... Cary, Shep and Nikki as they round the corner and pau breathless, to lean against a wall. Shep, his fist still weakly as Cary and Nikki stare at ...  ... Francis who briefly makes eye contact and then, witho steps over the rope and, pulling his jacket collar up aro off, instantly swallowed up by the darkness. Cary and Nikki stare after him, astonished.
That's the last of Francis, I'm  afraid. We'll never see him again.
Did you notice his eyes? That's the  first time I ever saw Francis really  happy. What'll happen to him, do you  suppose?
Don't worry about, Francis. He'll  take care of himself. Let's get out  of here. Let's walk.
Shep leans weakly against the wall, his eyes glassy.
No. Don't want to walk. Let's take  a cab.
Cary quickly moves to a signal a cab parked nearby. Nikki hand on Shep.

head_text.subj: THE BACK SEAT OF THE TAXI CAB

text: As the cab jolts down an uneven street and drives slowly carnival, the MUSIC continues. Cary and Shep sit on eithe is as edgy as Shep is subdued.
Did you see the way Francis poured  lead into that fellow?
Fast work.
Fast? Chain lightning!
Nice shooting.
Those slugs went right past my ear.  If I'd've moved an inch, I would've  caught one of them myself.
"Sudden Death," all right.
Nikki takes out a cigarette.
What's the matter with you, Shep?  I've never known you so quiet  before.
That's right. I am kind of quiet.
(holds her unlit  cigarette) Not smoking?
No.
Your lighter working?
Good ol', Nikki -- never has any  matches.
No.
As Shep puts his hand in his inside jacket pocket to pull lighter, a strange look crosses his face.
Sure you want a light?
That's what I want, a light.
Shep pulls out the lighter and flicks it on -- revealing white shirt. Nikki stares down at the blood in horror.
Shep. Shep!
Nikki jumps up and moves away from Shep, into a seat oppo
What is it?
Shep's hurt!
Cary turns to Shep, who slumps back weakly against his se look of release and satisfaction on his face.
It's a forgery.
Cary examines Shep, reaching in to feel his bloody wound.
Do something for him, Cary! Oh,  Shepard!
He's been shot!
What can we do, Cary?! What can we  do?!
Shep, why didn't you say you were  hurt?
Good old Cary. Sweet Nikki. You may  not believe it but this is the best  thing that ever happened to me.
Oh, Shep, Shep, don't say that.  You'll be all right. We'll get you  to a hospital.
Shep puts a hand on Cary's arm as the taxi continues to j street.
No, no, Cary. Don't rush me anywheres. Let's sit here for a while. The--  Hurts, the jolting.
Urgently, Cary reaches over and bangs on the glass betwee cab driver.
Stop! Stop!
In front of the carnival's slowly revolving carousel, the The carousel MUSIC drifts in. Shep hardly moves -- head b staring, voice dreamy and weak. Cary puts his face close intently.

That's better. You know, Cary, I feel - just like we're falling -- long  time ago. Do you remember? Spinning  ... spinning ... spinning. Only you  brought me down safe. Oh, Cary. Good  old Cary.  (sighs) Best flyer in the service.
Nikki, seated opposite, is distraught.
Oh, Shepard, Shepard, darling.
(reassuring) We're gonna make a safe landing  again, Shep.
Not this time, Cary. Ol' Shep's  gonna crash.  (beat) Say, but we're spinning fast. Level  off. Cary, level off.
Shep's head slumps down. His face presses against Cary's
Oh, Shepard, Shepard, darling.
Cary can't look at him. Eyes wide, Cary slowly presses hi
Shep? - Shep?! - Shep!
Cary looks as if he is on the verge of tears. And yet he to cry.
ROAR down a railroad track.

Nikki cranks her portable phonograph, turns it on and put record -- Toselli's "Serenade," that strange, sad composi Europe at the close of the Great War.  As the bittersweet romantic music plays, she listens for turns and sidles over to sit next to Cary who is seated b scribbling something on a piece of paper beside a small l
What are you writing, Cary?
A letter. A letter to Shep's mother.
Mind if I read it?
Certainly not.
Nikki reads the letter silently. A long pause.
Why, Cary. Cary, that's the most  beautiful letter I've ever read.
Nikki turns away and begins to cry, quietly.
Please forgive me for crying, Cary.  I can't help it. You don't mind if I  cry just a minute, do you?
No, Nikki.
Cary puts aside the letter.
Can't you cry, Cary?
No.
But you have cried sometime in your  life, haven't you?
Long, long time ago. Before the war.
And you can't cry now? Not even for  Shep?
Shep Lambert spent his life in the  war. He had nothing more to give. He  had died once. And he was ready to  die again.
This time he was played out with  music. That was the way he wanted it.
And Bill Talbot was a big success in  the hospital in his new blue shorts.  Maybe he'll tackle the angel Gabriel  and - be a big success again.
And Francis?

Maybe Francis will forget to wind  his chiming watch one day and go on  sleeping. Till the end. It doesn't  matter now. Without them, nothing  matters. We only had each other.  Comradeship was all we had left.  And now that's gone, too.
And you, Cary? You? You're alone  now.
That's right. I'm alone now.
I don't want you to be alone, Cary.  Let me stay with you. Let me be with  you.
He takes her hand, looks at her affectionately.
Why, Nikki. You're sweet.
He kisses her hand. A strange, apprehensive look crosses her hand over in his hands and opens it -- to reveal a he Cary looks at her in surprise.
Why, Nikki, you kept it. You didn't  forget.
She lowers her eyes for a moment, then looks at him.
No harm can come to our true love.

(amused, skeptical) No harm can come to our true love?  (genuinely) Oh, Nikki, you've become very dear  to me. I want to help you. Can't I  do something for you, too? What do  you want? What can I get you?
Well, I've always wanted a pair of  Spanish earrings.
He gives her an uncomprehending look but then breaks into buries her head lovingly in his shoulder. He kisses her h
in a dark, bleak landscape as it chugs away down the trac
